instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message:
Hey guys.

This one was working fine. Refused to turn on one day. NO drop. NO waterdamage.
Upon inspection found short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Removed short.

I cant see <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message:
So many questions..
Do you have a light/ any fan spin now? Where was the short and is it gone now? Did you replace the component? 
What do you mean you can’t see <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing?
How does <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, J4800/L4820/<CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message: You actually give no information....the usual plz. PPBUS, light?, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>? etc.

no light no fan spin
short was on <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> i found through flir
when i say pp5v is missing i mean its 0v
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, J4800/L4820/<CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> look fine

pp3v42 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message: Ok so you don't have 8.6 volts at PPBUS which is the problem. Is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message: No light and PPBUS at 8.2V means SMC is not running. Check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> and check for crap in SMC area or dead SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message: Did you try a good i/o board and cable? Good power supply?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message:
"Did you try a good i/o board and cable? Good power supply? "

I am sorry but this has NOTHING to do with PPBUS being 8.2V. That is just swapping parts and hoping it helps. You should diagnose, not swapping parts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message: n00b question,... can smc be replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No 5v
threads.message: Yes but has to come from identical donor board so has to come from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
